Courses           First-Year Program Offerings     Your education at Gallatin will begin with the First-Year Program, which is designed to provide you with a foundation for interdisciplinary study while fostering a sense of community and connections between your academic and extracurricular interests.    First-year students take three courses that constitute the First-Year Program: the First-Year Interdisciplinary Seminar and First-Year Writing Seminar (which you will take in the fall), and the First-Year Research Seminar (which you will take in the spring). Each seminar is organized around a particular theme with related readings that serve as springboards for discussion and models for students’ essays.   Below is a complete list of the First-Year Interdisciplinary Seminar and First-Year Writing Seminar offerings. Prepare for your pre-registration advising conversations by selecting your top five choices among the First-Year Interdisciplinary Seminars and First-Year Writing Seminars offered for Fall 2015.          The First-Year Interdisciplinary Seminar introduces students to the philosophy, goals, and methods of university education and to the interdisciplinary, individualized approach of the Gallatin School. These small classes of about 18 students encourage discussion rather than lecturing and focus on a theme that incorporates significant world texts representing several disciplines.  Course Detail                                        First-Year Writing Seminar: The Contents and Discontents of Marriage                                Semester and Year        FA 2015                    Course Number        FIRST-UG409                    Section        001                    Instructor        David Markus                    Days                            Tue,Thu                                 Time                            4:55 PM -       6:10 PM                                Units        4.0                    Level        U                    Foundation Requirement                                         Notes/Restrictions       Open to Gallatin first-year students only.                    Description       In this class we will look at how weddings and marriages have been represented in art and culture throughout modernity. We will investigate marriage as a celebration of love and union and as a system of religious, patriarchal, hetero-normative, and capitalistic exploitation and oppression. Through the analysis of key texts we will seek to understand why our longstanding cultural obsession with marriage—an institution often deemed outmoded—has continued to persist. Segments of the course will be devoted to representations of weddings and marriage in plays by Shakespeare and Edward Albee; in Jane Austen’s  Pride and Prejudice  ; in artworks by Jan van Eyck, Kiki Smith, Frieda Kahlo, and David Magnusson; in Ingmar Bergman’s  Scenes from a Marriage  and David Fincher’s  Gone Girl  ; and in contemporary popular songs such as Beyoncé’s “Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It).” We will also look at recent studies on marriage and divorce rates, discuss Bruce Benderson’s polemic,  Against Marriage  , and examine fissures in the LGBTQ community around the question of marriage equality. Students will collaborate through workshops and online, give in-class presentations, and complete a series of writing assignments around topics drawn from our objects of study. Description       In this class we will look at how weddings and marriages have been represented in art and culture throughout modernity. We will investigate marriage as a celebration of love and union and as a system of religious, patriarchal, hetero-normative, and capitalistic exploitation and oppression. Through the analysis of key texts we will seek to understand why our longstanding cultural obsession with marriage—an institution often deemed outmoded—has continued to persist. Segments of the course will be devoted to representations of weddings and marriage in plays by Shakespeare and Edward Albee; in Jane Austen’s  Pride and Prejudice  ; in artworks by Jan van Eyck, Kiki Smith, Frieda Kahlo, and David Magnusson; in Ingmar Bergman’s  Scenes from a Marriage  and David Fincher’s  Gone Girl  ; and in contemporary popular songs such as Beyoncé’s “Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It).” We will also look at recent studies on marriage and divorce rates, discuss Bruce Benderson’s polemic,  Against Marriage  , and examine fissures in the LGBTQ community around the question of marriage equality. Students will collaborate through workshops and online, give in-class presentations, and complete a series of writing assignments around topics drawn from our objects of study. University, 2003 MSt History of Art, University of Oxford, 2007           David Markus is a Ph.D. candidate in Comparative Literature at the University of Chicago. His research and teaching interests include 19th- and 20th-century American and European literature, visual art and culture, cinema, psychoanalytic theory, gender and sexuality, and theories of love. His dissertation examines how the myth of Orpheus is positioned within the work of modern and contemporary authors, artists, and theorists as a privileged text for thinking through the relationship between artistic ambition and the love relation.
